# Nasal Mask & Nasal Pillows



## Advantages
*   Talking
*   Eating
*   Expectoration
*   Lower risk of vomiting, asphyxia
*   Less claustrophobia



## Disadvantages
*   Not possible with nasal obstruction, mouth breathing in ARF
*   Nasal irritation, dryness, congestion
*   Leaks with mouth open
*   V$_T$ can't be measured
*   Dry mouth

---

<!-- Page 16 -->

Oronasal mask (Face mask) & Full face mask



### Advantages
*   Lesser air leak
*   Easier to fit
*   Preferred masks in case of in mouth breathing and acute respiratory failure



### Disadvantages
*   Vomiting, Aspiration, Asphyxia
*   Claustrophobia
*   Nasal, face pressure sores
*   Talking & coughing difficult
*   Drying of eyes

---

<!-- Page 17 -->

Oral Mask

*   Vomiting
*   Hypersalivation
*   Gastric distension
*   Talking & eating difficult
*   Pressure loss through nose

Used in neuromuscular disorders

## Helmet Mask



### Advantages:
*   Ability to deliver higher PEEP levels for prolonged durations because of minimal leak
*   No skin lesions or pressure ulcers due to the helmet's lack of contact with the face
*   Less resistance to flow
*   Can be applied regardless of the facial contour, facial trauma, or edentulism
*   Allows coughing
*   Less need for patient cooperation
*   Better comfort
*   Less interference with speech
*   Less risk of aerosol dispersion

---

<!-- Page 20 -->

Disadvantages
* Can not measure tidal volumes
* Asynchronies-trigger delay, slow pressurisation, cycling delay
* CO‚ÇÇ rebreathing
* Noise
* Edema of the limbs

---

<!-- Page 21 -->



# Choice of mask

*   In ARF Patients often start mouth breathing to bypass the higher resistance of the nose. This can result in mouth leaks and compromise the efficacy of ventilation if nasal masks are used.
*   All interfaces can be used to provide NIV successfully, but in the acute setting interfaces covering the mouth and nose are advantageous.
*   Try switching to a smaller interface once the patient is more stable.
*   There is currently no strong scientific evidence that one type of mask is necessarily or consistently better than others in terms of clinical efficiency.

---

<!-- Page 22 -->



# Selecting correct interface size

*   The nasal mask should fit just above the junction of the nasal bone and cartilage, directly at the sides of both nares, and just below the nose above the upper lip.
*   The oronasal mask should fit from just above the junction of the nasal bone and cartilage to just below the lower lip.

<!-- Page 25 -->



# CPAP & BPAP

*   **CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure)**
    *   Maintains a constant pressure throughout the breath

*   **BPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure)**
    *   Two levels of pressure applied
    *   Expiratory positive airway pressure/EPAP
    *   Inspiratory positive airway pressure/ IPAP
    *   Difference between IPAP & EPAP is pressure support
    *   Modes: Spontaneous (S), Timed (T), Spontaneous/Timed (S/T), PAC

---

<!-- Page 26 -->



# SPONTANEOUS MODE ( S )

*   Breaths are patient triggered & patient cycled
*   No option to set RR
*   RR is determined by the patient
*   Ventilator delivered breaths = patient's spontaneous RR

Disadvantages:

*   Patient's RR ‚Üì, ventilator delivered breaths ‚Üì
*   Ventilator will not deliver breaths if patient is not breathing

---

<!-- Page 27 -->



# TIMED MODE (T)

*   Breaths are machine triggered (time trigger) and machine cycled (time cycled)
*   Operator sets RR and inspiratory time
*   Ventilator starts IPAP after preset time interval (depends on set RR)
*   Ventilator switches to EPAP after preset inspiratory time

**Example**
*   Set RR 15 & inspiratory time 1 second
*   Ventilator delivers a breath after every 4 seconds (60/15=4)
*   Ventilator ends IPAP for 1 second (cycles into expiration/ starts EPAP)

**Disadvantage:**
*   Ventilator delivers fixed number of breaths regardless of the patient's spontaneous RR
*   Poorly tolerated by patients because of lack of interaction between the patient and ventilator
*   Used very rarely

---

<!-- Page 28 -->



# Spontaneous/ Timed (S/T)

Operator sets Back up RR
*   If the patient's RR > backup RR: Resembles spontaneous mode
*   If the patient's RR < backup RR: Resembles timed mode

---

**Spontaneous**

**Timed**

## S
Patient triggered & patient cycled
*   RR and inspiratory time are not preset
*   Patient initiates breath
*   Ventilator ends inspiratory phase after flow falls to certain level (flow/ patient cycling)
*   Ventilator delivered breaths= patient's respiratory rate



## S/T
*(No text visible in the image for this section)*



## T
Machine triggered & machine cycled
*   Preset RR and inspiratory time
*   Ventilator initiates a breath after predetermined time interval is reached (based on set RR)
*   Ventilator ends breath after predetermined inspiratory time
*   Ventilator delivers breaths at a fixed rate regardless of patient's RR

---

<!-- Page 38 -->



# Pressure Assist Control (PAC)

*   Operator sets back up RR and inspiratory time
*   If the patient's RR > set RR
    *   All breaths are patient triggered & machine cycled
*   If the patient's RR < set RR
    *   Breaths are machine triggered and machine cycled

---

<!-- Page 39 -->



## Timed Mode

*   Breaths are always machine triggered
*   Inspiratory time preset
    (Time/machine cycled breaths)
*   Ventilator delivers fixed number of breaths regardless of patient's spontaneous RR



## PAC

*   Machine triggered or patient triggered
*   Inspiratory time preset
    (Time/machine cycled breaths)
*   Patient determines RR
    *   Patient's RR > Backup RR
        Total number of breaths = backup RR
    *   Patient's RR < Backup RR
        Total number of breaths = patient's RR

<!-- Page 55 -->



# Goals of NIV

*   **Oxygenation**
    *   CPAP/EPAP/PEEP
        *   Alveolar recruitment
        *   Maintains upper airway patency
        *   Decreases work of breathing by counteracting the effects of auto PEEP

*   **CO‚ÇÇ removal**
*   **Unloading respiratory muscles**
    *   IPAP/PS
        *   Augments tidal volume & alveolar ventilation

---

<!-- Page 56 -->



# Physiological effects of NIV

*   Alveolar collapse
*   Alveolar oedema
*   Consolidation

These conditions contribute to:

*   V/Q mismatch
*   Shunt
*   Decreased compliance
*   Decreased FRC

These, in turn, lead to:

*   V/Q mismatch $\downarrow$ Hypoxia
*   Shunt $\downarrow$ Hypoxia
*   Decreased compliance $\downarrow$ Increased work of breathing, Respiratory muscle fatigue
*   Decreased FRC $\downarrow$ Increased work of breathing, Respiratory muscle fatigue

NIV (Non-Invasive Ventilation) addresses these issues:

*   Hypoxia $\uparrow$ NIV (via $\text{FiO}_2$)
*   NIV $\uparrow$ Decreased compliance (via $\text{EPAP/PEEP}$)
*   NIV $\uparrow$ Increased work of breathing, Respiratory muscle fatigue (via $\text{IPAP/PS}$)

---

<!-- Page 57 -->



# CPAP

*   CPAP increases FRC
*   Increases mean airway pressure
*   Maintains upper airway patency
*   Lung recruitment
*   Decreases work in case of auto PEEP
*   EPAP is necessary to ensure sufficient expiratory flow to flush carbon dioxide from the ventilatory dead space, enabling removal of carbon dioxide from the ventilator circuit and preventing rebreathing.
*   Fixed CPAP/ Auto CPAP
*   It does not unload respiratory muscles

---

<!-- Page 58 -->



## How to set CPAP/EPAP/PEEP?

*   Start with 3 to 5 cm H‚ÇÇO CPAP
*   1 cm H‚ÇÇO increments
*   Increase CPAP
    *   To relieve obstructive apneas
    *   To improve oxygenation
    *   Ineffective triggering in the presence of auto PEEP

* *Increase IPAP equal to EPAP increments to maintain a constant pressure support*

---

<!-- Page 59 -->

High PEEP
*   Leaks
*   Patient discomfort

Low PEEP
*   Ineffective triggering
*   Trigger delay
*   Upper airway obstructions leading to arousals

---

<!-- Page 60 -->



# IPAP & Pressure support

*   Provides ventilator assistance
*   Unloads inspiratory muscles
*   Decreases work of breathing
*   Augments tidal volume, minute ventilation, gas exchange

*   Critical care ventilators
    *   Pressure support is the pressure applied at the airway opening above the PEEP
    *   e.g. PEEP 5 and pressure support 10 cm H‚ÇÇO
    *   During inspiration airway pressure rises 10 cm H‚ÇÇO above PEEP. Total pressure 15 cmH‚ÇÇO
*   Bilevel ventilators
    *   IPAP is the pressure relative to atmosphere
    *   The difference between IPAP and EPAP is the Pressure support
    *   E.g. EPAP 5 cm H‚ÇÇO and IPAP 10 cm H‚ÇÇO.

---

sectionTitle: How to set IPAP / pressure support?
content:
# How to set IPAP / pressure support?

*   The difference between IPAP & EPAP should be 4 to 5 cm H‚ÇÇO
*   If the EPAP is 4, Starting IPAP 8
*   Starting pressure support 4 to 5 cm H‚ÇÇO
*   Increased gradually- 2 cm H‚ÇÇO increments- monitor ABG, RR, tidal volume, leaks
*   Increase pressure support/ IPAP
    *   To target a tidal volume of 6-8 ml/kg predicted body weight
    *   To reduce the work of breathing and RR
    *   To correct hypercapnia

---

<!-- Page 64 -->

* High pressures
    * High tidal volume
    * Ventilator over assistance
    * Leaks
    * Gastric distension/insufflation, vomiting, aspiration
    * Auto PEEP
    * Ineffective triggering, late cycling
* Low pressure support
    * Ventilator under assistance, dyspnoea
    * Hypercarbia
    * Increases work of breathing

---

<!-- Page 65 -->



# Respiratory Rate

*   Setting a backup respiratory rate ensures minimal ventilation when the patient is unable to trigger a mechanical breath.
*   The backup respiratory rate should be set to less than the patient's spontaneous respiratory rate to favour breaths triggered by the patient, which are more efficient and may also be more comfortable.
*   COPD- low RR
*   ARDS - high RR

---

<!-- Page 66 -->



# Rise Time

*   **PEEP**
*   **Pressure-Time**

The image displays three pressure-time waveforms, illustrating different "Rise Times".

1.  **Left (Blue Waveform):** Shows an almost instantaneous rise in pressure from the PEEP level to the peak inspiratory pressure, followed by a plateau and then a rapid drop back to PEEP. This represents a very fast rise time.
2.  **Middle (Red Waveform):** Shows a moderately sloped rise in pressure from the PEEP level to the peak inspiratory pressure, followed by a plateau and then a rapid drop back to PEEP. A double-headed arrow indicates the duration of this rise, labeled as "Rise Time".
3.  **Right (Green Waveform):** Shows a more gradual, slower rise in pressure from the PEEP level to the peak inspiratory pressure, followed by a plateau and then a rapid drop back to PEEP. A double-headed arrow indicates the duration of this rise, also labeled as "Rise Time", which is longer than the red waveform's rise time.

# T min

*   Minimum time ventilator spends in inspiratory phase
*   Safety feature that prevents early cycling
*   The minimum inspiratory time is usually set 0.2 seconds shorter than the insufflation time

E.g. T min setting 0.8 second
*   Ventilator prevents cycling to expiration before 0.8 second

---

<!-- Page 78 -->



# T max

*   Maximum time ventilator spends in inspiratory phase
*   Safety setting that prevents prolonged inspiration
*   The maximum inspiratory time is usually set 0.2 seconds longer than the insufflation time
*   E.g. T max setting 1.5 seconds

# Aerophagia

*   During NIV, the ventilation volume distributes between lungs and stomach depending on respiratory system resistance and lower oesophageal sphincter pressure (20-25 cm H‚ÇÇO).
*   Predisposing factors: large tidal volumes, high pressure setting, high airway resistance, low respiratory system compliance, short inspiratory time, short rise time.
*   Gastric distension compresses the lungs, thereby decreasing lung compliance and requiring higher airway ventilation pressure. The latter is also associated with increased risk of gastric distension, thus generating a vicious cycle.
*   Symptoms-bloating, abdominal distention, flatulence, or excessive belching

# COPD EXACERBATION



## INDICATIONS FOR NONINVASIVE MECHANICAL VENTILATION (NIV)

At least one of the following:
*   Respiratory acidosis (PaCO‚ÇÇ $\ge$ 6.0 kPa or 45 mmHg and arterial pH $\le$ 7.35).
*   Severe dyspnea with clinical signs suggestive of respiratory muscle fatigue, increased work of breathing, or both, such as use of respiratory accessory muscles, paradoxical motion of the abdomen, or retraction of the intercostal spaces.
*   Persistent hypoxemia despite supplemental oxygen therapy.

# INDICATIONS FOR INVASIVE MECHANICAL VENTILATION

*   Unable to tolerate NIV or NIV failure.
*   Status post - respiratory or cardiac arrest.
*   Diminished consciousness, psychomotor agitation inadequately controlled by sedation.
*   Massive aspiration or persistent vomiting.
*   Persistent inability to remove respiratory secretions.
*   Severe hemodynamic instability without response to fluids and vasoactive drugs.
*   Severe ventricular or supraventricular arrhythmias.
*   Life-threatening hypoxemia in patients unable to tolerate NIV.

ROLE IN COPD

1) To prevent acute respiratory acidosis, i.e. when the arterial CO2 tension (PaCO2) is normal or elevated but pH is normal
2) To prevent endotracheal intubation and invasive mechanical ventilation in patients with mild to moderate acidosis and respiratory distress, with the aim of preventing deterioration to a point when invasive ventilation would be considered
3) As an alternative to invasive ventilation in patients with severe acidosis and more severe respiratory distress
There is no lower limit of pH below which a trial of NIV is inappropriate
However, the lower the pH, the greater risk of failure, and patients must be very closely monitored with rapid access to endotracheal intubation and invasive ventilation if not improving.

# Cardiogenic Pulmonary edema

*   In CPE : **decreased respiratory system compliance** and alveolar flooding due to high capillary pressure associated or not with left ventricular systolic dysfunction
*   NIV (including both bilevel and **CPAP**) in this context has the ability to **improve respiratory mechanics** and facilitate **left ventricular work by decreasing left ventricular afterload** & facilitated by the decrease in negative pressure swings generated by the respiratory muscles.
*   **NIV is recommended** in hospital patients with **ARF**, due to **Cardiogenic pulmonary edema**. (**Strong recommendation**)

# NIV in de novo ARF?
[Hypoxemic]

De novo respiratory failure refers to respiratory failure occurring without prior chronic respiratory disease.

Most patients in this category have hypoxaemic respiratory failure, usually defined as significant hypoxaemia (PaO2/FIO2 <200), tachypnoea (respiratory rate >30-35 min and a non-COPD diagnosis (e.g. pneumonia and/or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)).

# ROLE in ARDS / PNEUMONIA

*   The main risk of NIV for the indication of de novo ARF is to delay a needed intubation
*   NIV may be used over conventional oxygen therapy in mild early acute hypoxemic respiratory failure (P/F ratio< 300 and > 200 mmHg), under close supervision.
*   Strong recommendation against a trial of NIV in patients with acute hypoxemic failure with P/F ratio < 150.

# Should NIV be used to prevent respiratory failure post-extubation?

*   NIV can be used to prevent post-extubation respiratory failure in high-risk patients post-extubation. (Conditional recommendation, low certainty of evidence.)
*   NIV should not be used to prevent post-extubation respiratory failure in non-high-risk patients.

**High Risk Patients**
*   More than one consecutive failure of weaning trial
*   Chronic heart failure
*   PaCO2 >45 mm Hg after extubation
*   More than one co-morbidity (excluding chronic heart failure)

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

# Stepwise reduction in NIV duration

*   Progressively reducing the duration of NIV over a period of 3-4 days
*   Initially weaning should be carried during daytime with overnight ventilation.
*   The daytime weaning can be divided into periods of 3 hours each and can be performed as follows ‚Äì
*   Day 1 : NIV 3 hours ON, 1 hour OFF (except during night period),
*   Day 2 : NIV 3 hours ON, 2 hours OFF (except during night period) and
*   DAY 3 : NIV can be used only during the night period.
*   NIV may be discontinued on day 4 unless continuation is clinically indicated for example, few hours daytime and six hours or more overnight.
